journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Effects of temperature and strain rate on the dynamic responses of three polymer-bonded explosives

article-meta.aff: 1School of Science, National University of Defense and Technology, People’s Republic of China
2Institute of Fluid Physics, Chinese Academy of Engineering and Physics, People’s Republic of China
3Institute of Chemical Materials, Chinese Academy of Engineering and Physics, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: FY Lu, School of Science, National University of Defense and Technology, Changsha, Hunan, 410073, People’s Republic of China. Email: fylu@nudt.edu.cn; jl_lee@nudt.edu.cn

abstract.p: Polymer-bonded explosives (PBXs) are typical particulate composites of energetic crystals in a polymer matrix, which have a volume fraction of 60% to 95%. They are engineered to provide reliable performance and maximum safety envelopes through reduction of their sensitivity. There are three kinds of polymer-bonded explosive materials; namely, PBX1, PBX2, and PBX3. The last two polymer-bonded explosives were recently invented, in search of the more insensitive polymer-bonded explosive but with high detonation energy also. To investigate the dynamic response of new materials, the uniaxial compressive stress–strain behavior of the three polymer-bonded explosives was investigated as a function of temperature and strain rate. Constant and non-constant strain rate loading experiments were conducted in the use of pulse shapers. By comparing two different loads, the strain rate effect of these materials was found to depend on the instantaneous strain rate. The variations in failure stress, and failure strain with temperature, strain rate, and material composition were examined. The dependence of compressive strength on temperature and strain rate can be attributed to the Young’s modulus and fracture surface energy according to Griffith criteria for fracture. The axial splitting caused by brittle fracture for most conditions was also investigated. Another failure mode of PBX2 agreed with the Mohr’s failure mode criterion. All results show that PBX2 has more stable mechanical behavior and higher detonation performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of explosives has drawn people’s attention since they were invented. This concern emerged mainly due to the occurrence of unexpected explosions that result in fatalities and major economic losses. A number of studies have focused on the development of safer but more violent explosives.1–6 At present, polymer-bonded explosives (PBXs) are adopted widely because of their low sensitivity and high detonation energy. PBXs are similar to particle-reinforced composites, which are composed mainly of energetic crystals and matrices, including polymer binders, plasticizers, and so on. Different kinds of energetic crystals, polymer binders, and their distribution cause changes in the mechanical behavior of PBX materials.5–9 Therefore, determining how these factors affect the macro-mechanical behavior of PBX is important.10,11

Generally, polymer-based materials have non-linear mechanical properties which are highly temperature dependent.12–14 Gray III et al. have obtained high strain rate (2000 s−1) compression measurements using a specially designed Split Hopkinson Pressure Bars (SHPB) as a function of temperature from −55 to +50 °C for PBX9501.15,16 Jaw and Lee have focused on the thermal characteristics of various explosives and the compatibility of the two previously mentioned explosives with silicone rubber, as well as their decomposition kinetic parameters.17,18

PBXs behave quite differently at high strain rates compared with quasi-static cases.19 The strength of the material, which is represented by the maximum stress, increases as the strain rate increases. This dependence is also influenced by ambient temperature.20 Explosives are initiated earlier than expected when the temperature changes or when they are triggered by shock waves. If placed in outer space, the properties of the materials used also change because of temperature variations. Therefore, the examination of the dynamic behavior of temperature-dependent materials has become an emerging focus in weapon design. This issue also has an important application value in many fields, including penetration, protection from explosion, explosive weld, and so on.

SHPB has become a widely used technique to measure the uniaxial compressive stress–strain relationship of various materials in the strain rate range of 102 to 104 s−1. In traditional SHPB tests, the stress state of specimen is assumed to one dimensional stress. Thus, it is easy to construct the failure plane in stress principal axes for further describing the constitutive model of PBX. The PBX may be damaged or failed under a subtle stimulation, and the low-strength impact can be realized by use of SHPB. The stress, strain, and strain rate history of a specimen can be calculated using the records on incident and transmitted bars based on the one-dimensional wave propagation theory. In an effort to understand newly manufactured PBXs, uniaxial compressive experiments were conducted with different strain rates (50–850 s−1) and different temperatures (25, 50, and 65 °C) using SHPB in the present work.

sec.title: Experimental designs
sec.p: Triaminotrinitrobenzene (TATB) is a famous insensitive explosive, but its explosion energy and generated heat are relatively low. Comparatively, high-melting explosive (HMX) has high degrees of density, energy, and explosion heat, but it also has a high degree of stiffness and sensitivity. A PBX containing HMX, together with enough polymers, has better mechanical behavior but greatly decreased explosion behavior. The addition of TATB into HMX can depress the sensitivity of HMX by shortening the length of N-NO2 to strengthen chemical bonding21 while causing very little change in explosion behavior. Therefore, finding out the best proportion of TATB and HMX in the formulation of a PBX may be a feasible method in the development of insensitive explosives.

One PBX, adding TATB into HMX with a volume fraction of 8%, has been widely adopted in many weapon systems, but the safety behavior of the PBX is not so satisfying. In search for the most insensitive explosives that have a high detonation behavior, much more TATB were added. Therefore, two PBXs, namely, PBX2 (volume fraction: HMX/TATB/polymers=40%/56%/4%) and PBX3 (volume fraction: HMX/TATB/polymers=55%/41%/4%), were newly engineered. For comparison, PBX1 (TATB/polymers=95%/5%) was also investigated. The three PBXs had similar particle size distributions and were machined using the same pressing and cutting processes. To minimize the effect of binder discrepancy on materials’ mechanical responses, two new PBXs have the same binder components.

SHPB experiments using three different temperatures (25, 50, and 65 °C) were conducted to determine the effects of temperature on the three PBXs (Figure 1). Each specimen was heated adequately to ensure a uniform temperature. For the aluminum bars, a heating stove was used to heat the bar ends to the same temperature state in order to prevent heat changes in the specimen while testing. The effect of temperature on the bars’ strain was excluded in our experimental temperature range. A thermoelectric couple was embedded in the transmitted bar adjacent to the specimen to detect instantaneously the temperature of the bars. The strain rate, strain, and stress in the specimen can be calculated using the following standard Hopkinson bar data reduction equations when the dynamic stress equilibrium was achieved

where εi(t), εr(t), and εt(t) are the incident, reflected, and transmitted strain histories, respectively; A0 is the cross-sectional area of the bars; E0 and c0 are the Young’s modulus and elastic wave speed of the bar material, respectively; and As and ls are the initial cross-sectional area and length of the specimen, respectively.

Brass is adopted widely as a pulse shaper material in SHPB. A constant strain rate can be achieved using a proper diameter and length for the brass pulse shaper. The original records obtained using an oscillograph are shown in Figure 2, and three strain rate loadings are also presented. The reflected pulse has a flat curve, representing a constant strain rate load. The points at which the curves rise again reflect the beginning of specimen failure.

caption.p: Constant strain rate loads using brass pulse shaper.

sec.p: The strain rate seems to be limited to a critical value for a certain size combination of the specimen and striker. A higher strain rate can be achieved with the use of a rubber shaper on condition that the stress equilibrium is achieved. However, constant strain rate loads cannot be realized at high loads (Figure 3). The initial part of each load increases slowly, so the specimen has enough time to achieve stress equilibrium. These curves do not show the failure point, so the time corresponding to the peak of the transmitted wave will be referred to.

caption.p: Non-constant strain rate loads using rubber pulse shaper.

sec.title: Stress–strain curves
sec.p: A constant strain rate can minimize the inertia effect of the SHPB system. Therefore, the results of the experiments using a brass pulse shaper are first discussed. At normal temperature, PBX1 seems to be independent of strain rate (Figure 4(a)). However, as the temperature increases, the strain rate effect becomes obvious. The figures show that the maximum stress decreases at high temperatures.

caption.p: Stress–strain curves of PBX1: (a) results of constant strain rate loads using a brass pulse shaper, (b) results of non-constant strain rate loads using a rubber pulse shaper.

sec.p: PBX2 is dependent on the strain rate at room temperature (Figure 5(a)). However, at 50 °C, the difference among the three strain rates is insignificant. Strengths, which are represented by the maximum stress, reach a level of uncertainty at approximately 50 °C. At 65 °C, the discrepancy becomes larger as the strain rate varies, and the highest strength is only slightly less than that achieved at 50 °C. These results indicate an apparent change in the mechanical behavior of the materials at temperatures close to or below 50 °C.

caption.p: Stress–strain curves of PBX2: (a) results of constant strain rate loads using a brass pulse shaper, (b) results of non-constant strain rate loads using a rubber pulse shaper.

sec.p: The maximum stresses of PBX3 do not change as much as those of PBX2 and PBX3 even when the temperature and strain rate vary (Figure 6(a)). Overall, PBX3 is found to be the most brittle. The obtained stresses decrease rapidly after the peak value is achieved as the strain increases in most experiments. Once a specimen reaches the critical state of fracture, inner cracks in PBX3 will spread rapidly, causing specimen crushing.

caption.p: Stress–strain curves of PBX3: (a) results of constant strain rate loads using a brass pulse shaper, (b) results of non-constant strain rate loads using a rubber pulse shaper.

sec.p: The stress–strain curves of non-constant strain rate loading tests are quite similar to those of the constant strain rate loading cases (Figures 4 to 6). In subsequent analysis, the instantaneous strain rate will be proven to satisfy the mechanical parameter variation rule of the experiment results. Compared to constant strain rate loading, the strengths do not have obvious increase at the same level of strain rate, indicating that the radial inertia effect on strength caused by non-constant strain rate loading can be ignored. There are two curves that are almost the same at 65 °C, and their strain rates, which are 460 and 470 s−1, respectively, are also nearly the same (Figure 5(b)). This indirectly proves experimental repetition of a rubber pulse shaper. Notably, there is another limitation in terms of strain rate in the use of a rubber shaper when the stress equilibrium state has been satisfied.22 The largest strain rates of PBX1, PBX2, and PBX3 are 850, 600, and 470 s−1, respectively.

In the case of multi-shock waves, the ignition behavior will depend on the mechanical feature and strength of the energetic materials. As the strain rate increases, the strengths of the three materials also increase. A specimen would break into pieces because of the large strain energy released by a fracture. At high temperatures, shear bands would develop to prevent fracturing, thereby leading to a higher failure strain. PBX3 is the most brittle material. PBX2 seems brittle at normal temperature, but at 65 °C, the stress after the peak decreases slowly. PBX1 has a similar behavior at both 50 and 65 °C. Before macro-failure, mechanical damage (including cracks and holes) causes a specimen to develop a critical state of fracture. Further, polymer binders are responsible for changing the behavior of the materials from fragility to ductility at a higher temperature.

sec.title: Temperature and strain rate effects
sec.p: The effects of temperature and strain rate on mechanical parameters such as the failure stress, and failure strain of each PBX and the differences among them will be discussed in this section. For a non-constant strain rate, the strain rate should be determined when the maximum stress occurs as the loading strain rate. Comparing the results of the two different loading methods, those obtained with the use of a rubber pulse shaper have the same variation tendency in strain rate and temperature as those with the use of a brass pulse shaper. PBXs are all particulate composites so they behave as a discrete medium. Each mechanical parameter also exhibits dispersiveness at different extents.

sec.title: Failure strength
sec.p: The maximum stress has been regarded previously as the failure stress or strength. The strength depends on the strain rate, which is apparently linear in the range of 101 to 103 s−1 (Figure 7). The slopes for this linear relationship increase as the temperature increases. The influence of high strain rate on the strength of a material is not only reflected by the material’s capability to withstand deformation but also by the relationship between crack velocity and deformation velocity. Initially, polymers endure applied load through distortion, and they have viscous features related to the strain rate.

caption.p: Failure stress variations with temperature and strain rate: (a) PBX1, (b) PBX2, (c) PBX3.

sec.p: On the other hand, the velocity of crack spreading in polymer binders confines the debonding process to achieve further development, resulting in an increase in strength. The interactions between components weaken as the temperature increases, resulting in a decrease in strength. The increase in strain rate is more obvious at high temperatures for all the materials.

At the same temperature and strain rate, the order is PBX1<PBX2<PBX3 in terms of strength. The strength of PBX depends on the interaction among compositions or the binding energy among all molecules. Based on MD computation,21 the binding energy between TATB/binder is the largest (1274 kJ•mol−1), followed by that between HMX/TATB (1087.7 kJ•mol−1) and that between HMX/binder (394 kJ•mol−1). The strength of single crystals in TATB is lower than that of single crystals in HMX. PBX1 containing only TATB experimentally has the lowest strength, and PBX3 containing the least TATB has the highest strength. Therefore, the fracturing of crystals may lead to the failure of a specimen.

A number of studies have indicated that the compressive failure of PBX is also caused by the tensile fracture process. For brittle material, Wiegand and Pinto20 have indicated that there is a linear relation between the compressive strength and the tensile fracture strength under uniaxial loading. Although the tensile strengths of the PBXs are unknown currently, the Griffith’s theory may explain relation between the temperature and the failure stress. According to Griffith’s theory, the pressure on cracks decreases the elastic energy of the entire system. Assuming that the net reduction in elastic energy is W, and 2cc is the initial crack length, cracks would spread, leading to specimen fracture, only when dW/dc≤0. In the case of tension, the formula can be expressed as follows

where σT is the tensile strength, E is the Young’s modulus, and γ is the fracture surface energy. The influence of temperature on the compressive strength of the materials may be attributed partially to the modulus and fracture surface energy. The modulus of polymers decreases with an increase in temperature, facilitating the easier separation of polymers from crystals for the formation of interface micro-cracks. At high temperatures, the interaction between all kinds of molecules is also weakened, thereby decreasing the fracture surface energy. Hence, the tensile strength decreases as the temperature increases. And thus, the experimental compressive strength decreases as the temperature increases. In further investigation of the failure mechanism of PBX, the variation law of the fracture surface energy γ and Young’s modulus E with the temperature need to be obtained, and the numerical relation between the tensile strength and the compressive strength also needs to be found out. Then, the compressive failure stress may be numerically predicted using Griffith’s theory.

sec.title: Failure strain
sec.p: The failure strains of the three PBXs do not show major variations (Figure 8). However, the failure strains are fitted in a linear manner for simplicity. The failure strain of PBX1 increases with the strain rate. At 25 °C, the linear relationship corresponds well with the results. There are some fluctuations at higher temperatures. PBX2 is most stable because its failure strains change least with the temperature and strain rate. Polymers can distort themselves at a larger scale to protect crystals from fracturing, allowing the specimen to sustain a level of strain up to 0.1. Despite having the largest failure stress, PBX3 has the largest fluctuations in terms of failure strains.

caption.p: Failure strain variations with temperature and strain rate: (a) PBX1, (b) PBX2, (c) PBX3.

sec.p: In summary, the strength of PBX1 is the lowest, but its failure strain is the highest, indicating that PBX1 has the lowest sensitivity. PBX3, which contains the greatest amount of HMX, may have the best detonation performance, but results show that it is still very brittle and inflexible. PBX2 also exhibits better mechanical properties because its failure strain is highly stable even when the temperature and loading strain rate change. PBX2 also has relatively high explosion energy.

sec.title: Failure mode
sec.p: The critical condition for failure is strain and not stress, which is the more common case. Strain-caused failure can be critical because materials need to detach irreversibly the filler from the binder (interface failure) in the composites or to fracture crystals irreversibly, both of which may not depend on the temperature and strain rate. For brittle materials, a common failure mode under uniaxial compression is assumed to be a radial tensile fracture (or axial splitting) caused by Poisson’s effect. When compressed axially, the specimen would dilate radially, which results in the spread of cracks along the axial of the applied stress.

However, one special failure mode in the conducted tests is shown in Figure 9. All cracks, whether on the surface or inside the specimen, developed in directions at a 60° angle from the direction of the radial axes. This result is similar to that obtained by Griffith on glass several decades ago (represented by Wiegand and Pinto20).

caption.p: Failure modes of specimen: (a) PBX2-140 s−1–25 °C, (b) PBX2-210 s−1–50 °C, (c) PBX2-240 s−1–25 °C, (d) PBX2-230 s−1−65 °C.

sec.p: A part of the failed specimen in Figure 9(c) is conical, which has a strict axial symmetry. Only PBX2 has this standard failure mode, which often occurs when loading at a non-constant strain rate. This fracture feature implies that PBX2 has a better internal structure to serve as a regular material like metal. It may be explained by that PBX2 can initially endure the radial tension caused by Poisson’s effect. There is another kind of mechanism controlling the failure of PBX2. It should be noted that the angles are almost the same, although the strain rate variations are significant, indicating that these angles reflect the inner property of the material, like friction angle. In the literature, the failure mode criterion relating to the Coulomb criterion is often used.23 All Mohr’s circles of stress that fulfill the Coulomb criterion have two symmetrically positioned straight lines as their envelopes. These straight lines can be written as

where κ and µ are non-negative material parameters. Consider the stress state (σ, τ) that satisfies the Coulomb criterion (equation 5) in accordance with Figure 10(a). It is assumed that the plane illustrated in Figure 10(b) on which the failure stresses σ and τ act is also a failure plane where failure takes place in the form of sliding. From Mohr’s circle of stress, the corresponding interpretation of σ and τ displayed in Figure 10(b) where the x1x2x3-coordinate system is collinear with the principal directions of σ1, σ2 and σ3. From Figure 10(a) follows that α=45°−φ/2, where α is the angle between the normal of the failure surface and the largest stress principal direction and φ denotes the friction angle. The angle β which the failure plane makes with the largest principal stress direction (σ1) becomes β=45°+φ/2 as shown in Figure 10(b).

caption.p: (a) Coulomb criterion and Mohr’s circle; (b) Interpretation of σ and τ23

sec.p: Here, the tension is considered as a positive quantity. For compression tests, the friction angle φ of PBX is usually assumed to be 30°, and then the angle β is calculated as 60°. The angle between the experimental failure plane and the largest principal stress is about 60° (Figure 9(b)). It turns out that Mohr’s failure mode criterion is in fair agreement with the experimental results. But if there is obvious plasticity of other materials, the failure angle would be raised by the so-called non-associated plasticity.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Dynamic compression tests have been performed on three PBXs with different temperatures and strain rates. The compressive strengths of each material decrease with an increase in temperature and increase with an increase in strain rate. The dependence of compressive strength on temperature and strain rate can be attributed to the Young’s modulus and fracture surface energy. The strain rate sensitivity is relatively small, especially in the strain rate range of 50 to 850 s−1. The failure strains of each material are nearly insensitive to the temperature and strain rate, and can be adopted as the criterion for failure. The failure mode of PBX2 agreed with the Mohr’s failure mode criterion. Among the three PBXs, PBX2 has the best mechanical properties and relatively higher explosive energy, and may be widely applied in weapon systems.
